That might involve one substitution—breaking the carboxylic acid—but also potentially another substitution to form the amide. Hmm, maybe just one substitution here too.

chunk_resampled: Starting with a), glutamic acid to lysine.
rollout:
Starting with a), glutamic acid to lysine. Glutamic acid has an R-H bond on the arginine side chain, which means it can donate a hydrogen more easily than normal arginine. Lysine, on the other hand, doesn't have this H-bonding ability, so converting glutamic acid to lysine would require replacing that extra hydrogen. That sounds like just one substitution.

Next, b) leucine to alanine. Leucine has an N-terminal H, which allows it to donate a hydrogen more readily. Alanine, however, lacks both N-terminal and C-terminal hydrogens. So to convert leucine to alanine, we'd need to remove two hydrogens. That makes two substitutions needed here.

Moving on to c) phenylalanine to glycine. Phenylalanine has an N-terminal H, while glycine doesn't. To get rid of the N-terminal H in phenylalanine, you need one substitution. Additionally, since glycine doesn't have any hydrogens (both N and C terminals are missing), there's no need to substitute those either. So only one substitution is required here.

For d) tryptophan to serine. Tryptophan has multiple H-bonds available (N-terminal, C-terminal, and S-terminal), whereas serine doesn't have any. So to convert tryptophan to serine, you have to remove all three H-bonds. That should be three substitutions.

Finally, e) valine to glutamic acid. Valine has both N-terminal and C-terminal hydrogens but lacks the S-terminal. Glutamic acid has both N and C, as well as the S-terminal. So to go from valine to glutamic acid, you'll need to add the S-terminal. That adds one substitution.

Putting it all together:
a) 1 substitution
b) 2 substitutions
c) 1 substitution
